_note: Custom games created by users will appear in the 'My Games' tab, not in the 'By Difficulty' tab. This file contains the standard game collection organized by difficulty.

games.name: Fool's Mate

moves_detailed.description: White plays f3, weakening the king's diagonal
moves_detailed.commentary: A terrible move! White weakens the king's position by moving the f-pawn, which removes the natural defense of the g1-a7 diagonal. This creates a fatal weakness that Black can exploit.

moves_detailed.description: Black plays e5, controlling the center
moves_detailed.commentary: A good developing move. Black controls the center and prepares to bring out pieces. More importantly, this move opens the diagonal for the queen to attack White's weakened king position.

moves_detailed.description: White plays g4, further weakening the king's position
moves_detailed.commentary: An absolutely catastrophic move! White further weakens the king's position by moving the g-pawn, creating a massive hole in the king's defense. This is the final mistake that allows Fool's Mate - Black can now deliver checkmate in one move.

moves_detailed.description: Black delivers checkmate with the queen
moves_detailed.commentary: Checkmate! Black delivers the fastest possible checkmate in chess. The queen attacks the king on h4, and White has no way to defend or escape. This is Fool's Mate - a perfect example of how weak opening moves can lead to immediate disaster.

games.facts: Fool's Mate is the fastest possible checkmate in chess, occurring in just 2 moves. It requires White to make two extremely weak moves (f3 and g4) that severely weaken the king's position. This pattern is rarely seen in actual games as it requires White to make such poor moves that most players would never consider them. The name 'Fool's Mate' comes from the fact that only a fool would make such terrible moves. This checkmate pattern is often used as a teaching tool to demonstrate the importance of king safety in the opening.

games.name: Scholar's Mate

moves_detailed.description: e4
e5
Qh5
Black develops the knight to c6
moves_detailed.commentary: A natural developing move, but it doesn't address White's threat.

moves_detailed.description: White develops the bishop to c4, supporting the queen
moves_detailed.commentary: White develops the bishop to c4, creating a powerful battery with the queen. Now both pieces are attacking the vulnerable f7 square. The threat is becoming very serious.

moves_detailed.description: Black develops the knight to f6, attacking the queen
moves_detailed.commentary: A critical mistake! Black attacks the queen but doesn't realize that White can simply move the queen to f7 for checkmate. This is the final blunder that allows the Scholar's Mate to be completed - White can now deliver checkmate in one move.

moves_detailed.description: White delivers checkmate with Qf7#
moves_detailed.commentary: Checkmate! White delivers the final blow by moving the queen to f7. The king is trapped and has no escape squares. This is the classic Scholar's Mate pattern - a quick checkmate that demonstrates the importance of defending the f7 square in the opening.

games.facts: Scholar's Mate, also known as the 'Four-Move Checkmate', is one of the most famous quick checkmate patterns in chess. It targets the f7 square, which is only defended by the king in the starting position. This pattern is commonly attempted by beginners but is easily defended against by experienced players. The name 'Scholar's Mate' comes from the fact that it was often used to defeat inexperienced players (scholars) in the 19th century. Despite being easily refuted, this pattern teaches important lessons about piece development, king safety, and the importance of defending weak squares in the opening.

games.name: Légal Trap

moves_detailed.description: White opens with e4, controlling the center
moves_detailed.commentary: The most popular opening move, controlling the center and freeing the queen and bishop for development.

moves_detailed.description: Black responds with e5, mirroring white's strategy
moves_detailed.commentary: The symmetrical response, also controlling the center. This leads to an open game with equal chances.

moves_detailed.description: White develops the knight to f3, attacking e5
moves_detailed.commentary: Natural development, attacking the e5 pawn and preparing for castling. This is the most common move in this position.

moves_detailed.description: Black plays d6, supporting e5 and preparing Philidor Defense
moves_detailed.commentary: The Philidor Defense. Black supports the e5 pawn and prepares to develop the bishop to e7. This is a solid but somewhat passive approach.

moves_detailed.description: White develops the bishop to c4, targeting f7
moves_detailed.commentary: White develops the bishop to an active square, targeting the vulnerable f7 square. This is a natural developing move in this position.

moves_detailed.description: Black develops the bishop to g4, pinning the knight
moves_detailed.commentary: Black pins the knight to the queen, but this is a mistake in this position. The pin looks strong but actually allows White to execute a famous tactical combination. Black should have played Be7 or Nf6 instead.

moves_detailed.description: White develops the knight to c3, preparing the trap
moves_detailed.commentary: White develops the knight to c3, which looks like a normal developing move. However, this sets up the famous Légal Trap. The knight on c3 will play a crucial role in the coming combination.

moves_detailed.description: Black plays g6, weakening the kingside
moves_detailed.commentary: A critical mistake! Black weakens the kingside with g6, which will prove fatal. This move creates the perfect conditions for White's tactical combination. Black should have played Nf6 or Be7 to continue normal development.

moves_detailed.description: White captures e5 with the knight, sacrificing the queen
moves_detailed.commentary: The famous sacrifice! White captures the e5 pawn with the knight, apparently falling into Black's trap of losing the queen. However, this is actually the beginning of a brilliant tactical combination. If Black captures the queen, White will have a forced mate in 3 moves. White has calculated that the material sacrifice will be more than compensated by the mating attack.

moves_detailed.description: Black captures the queen with the bishop
moves_detailed.commentary: Black falls into the trap! By capturing the queen, Black has walked into White's tactical combination. This move looks natural but is actually a fatal mistake that leads to mate in 2. Black should have played Bxe5 instead, though even then White would have a strong position.

moves_detailed.description: White plays Bxf7+, delivering check
moves_detailed.commentary: Brilliant! White delivers a devastating check with Bxf7+. This move attacks the king and forces Black to move, while also setting up the final mating pattern. The bishop sacrifice is the key to the whole combination - it opens up the position and creates the conditions for mate in 2 moves.

moves_detailed.description: Black moves the king to e7, the only legal move
moves_detailed.commentary: The only legal move for the king. Black is forced to move to e7, but this exposes the king and makes it vulnerable to White's mating attack. The king is now in the center of the board with no protection. White can now deliver checkmate in one move with Nd5#.

moves_detailed.description: White delivers checkmate with Nd5#
moves_detailed.commentary: Checkmate! A beautiful finish to the Légal Trap! The knight on c3 delivers the final blow by moving to d5, giving checkmate. The knight is supported by the bishop on f7, and Black's king has no escape squares. This is one of the most famous tactical combinations in chess history, demonstrating the power of piece coordination and tactical vision.

games.facts: The Légal Trap is one of the most famous tactical combinations in chess history, named after Legall de Kermeur who played it in 1750. This trap demonstrates the power of piece coordination and tactical vision. The key insight is that material advantage (having a queen) is less important than having a winning position. This game is studied by chess players of all levels as a perfect example of how to recognize and execute tactical combinations.

games.name: Blackburn Schilling Trap
games.description: Famous miniature. Black mates under 10 moves!

moves_detailed.description: White opens with e4, claiming the center.
Black mirrors with e5, controlling the center.
White develops knight, attacking e5.
Black defends e5 with knight development.
White develops bishop, eyeing f7.
Black plays Nd4, a mistake.
moves_detailed.commentary: This odd knight move is not sound but invites White to grab a pawn. Black is hoping White falls for the trap.

moves_detailed.description: White captures e5, also a mistake.
moves_detailed.commentary: This is the critical mistake. White thinks they win a free pawn on e5, but this walks right into Black's trap.

moves_detailed.description: Black counters with Qg5, attacking g2.
White sacrifices knight on f7 for attack.
moves_detailed.commentary: White takes the f7 pawn, thinking they fork the rook and queen. This looks tempting but is a serious blunder in the trap line.

moves_detailed.description: Black captures g2, threatening mate.
White defends against mate with Rf1.
Black checks by capturing on e4.
White blocks the check with Be2.
Black delivers checkmate with Nf3#
moves_detailed.commentary: The knight delivers a beautiful smothered mate (king trapped by its own pieces).

games.facts: Blackburne Shilling Gambit: a fruitful source of income for Manchester(England)-born Joseph Henry Blackburne (1841-1924) when playing café visitors, the usual stake being one shilling. Black's third move may not be good enough for master chess but it is not an outright error and cannot be refuted by violence.

games.name: NN – Du Mont, 1802
games.description: Bird's Opening trap – queen sacrifice leads to devastating mate

moves_detailed.description: White plays Bird's Opening
moves_detailed.commentary: Weakens the kingside and neglects development.

moves_detailed.description: Black responds with e5
White captures the e5 pawn
moves_detailed.commentary: Pawn grabbing in the opening.

moves_detailed.description: Black challenges the pawn
White captures the d6 pawn
moves_detailed.commentary: Opens lines at the cost of king safety.

moves_detailed.description: Black recaptures with the bishop
moves_detailed.commentary: Develops with tempo and targets the kingside.

moves_detailed.description: White plays g3
moves_detailed.commentary: Fatal dark-square weakening.

moves_detailed.description: Black's queen enters the attack
moves_detailed.commentary: Directly prepares the attack.

moves_detailed.description: White develops the knight
Black sacrifices the queen
moves_detailed.commentary: Decisive queen sacrifice.

moves_detailed.description: White captures the queen
Black delivers checkmate
moves_detailed.commentary: Mate exploiting the exposed king.

games.facts: A classic miniature from 1802 demonstrating the dangers of the Bird's Opening when played carelessly. White's pawn-grabbing and failure to develop allows Black to launch a devastating attack. The queen sacrifice on g3 is one of the most famous tactical patterns in this opening.

games.name: Tchinenoff – Maillard, 1925
games.description: King's Gambit trap – White's fxe5 blunder allows instant checkmate

moves_detailed.description: White opens with e4, controlling the center
Black responds with e5, controlling the center
White plays the King's Gambit, offering the f-pawn
Black develops the bishop to c5, accepting the gambit
White captures e5 with the f-pawn
moves_detailed.commentary: This is the critical mistake. White thinks they win a free pawn on e5, but this walks right into Black's trap. The typical continuation is 3.Nf3, but after 3.Nf3 Qh4+ 4.Ke2 Qxe4# White is also mated—this is not a good way to play the King's Gambit!

moves_detailed.description: Black's queen enters with check
moves_detailed.commentary: Black's queen storms in with a devastating check. The diagonal to White's king is now open.

moves_detailed.description: White moves the king to escape check
Black delivers checkmate
moves_detailed.commentary: Checkmate! The queen captures on e4 and delivers the final blow. White's king has no escape.

games.facts: A classic King's Gambit trap from Paris, 1925. White's greedy 3.fxe5 instead of the normal 3.Nf3 allows Black to deliver a swift checkmate with the queen. The game demonstrates why developing pieces (Nf3) is more important than grabbing material in the opening—and that even the 'normal' 3.Nf3 line leads to mate after Qh4+ and Qxe4#, showing the dangers of the King's Gambit when not played precisely.

games.name: Reti – Tartakower, 1910
games.description: Caro-Kann trap – White sacrifices queen for unstoppable mating attack

moves_detailed.description: White opens with e4, controlling the center
Black plays the Caro-Kann Defense
White claims the center with d4
Black challenges the center
White develops the knight
Black captures the e4 pawn
White recaptures with the knight
Black develops the knight
White develops the queen to d3
Black strikes in the center
White captures the e5 pawn
Black's queen checks from a5
White blocks the check with the bishop
Black captures the knight on e4
moves_detailed.commentary: Takes the knight on e4, but this allows White to initiate a mating sequence; the king becomes exposed.

moves_detailed.description: White castles queenside
moves_detailed.commentary: Ignores the knight and prepares Qd8+; the d-file opens and White threatens an unstoppable mate.

moves_detailed.description: Black's knight moves to e4
White's queen delivers check
Black captures the queen with the king
moves_detailed.commentary: Capturing the queen seems natural, but the king is drawn into a forced mating net.

moves_detailed.description: White's bishop delivers check
Black's king moves to c7
moves_detailed.commentary: The only legal move; the king is forced to c7 where it will be trapped.

moves_detailed.description: White delivers checkmate with the bishop
moves_detailed.commentary: Checkmate: the king is trapped by its own pieces and has no escape.

games.facts: A famous miniature from Vienna, 1910. Reti, playing White, allows Black to capture his knight with the queen, then ignores the threat and castles queenside. The queen sacrifice on d8 draws Black's king into the center, and the bishop pair delivers a beautiful checkmate. A classic example of prioritizing attack over material.

games.name: Morphy – Duke Karl, 1858
games.description: The Opera Game - One of the most famous games in chess history

moves_detailed.description: White opens with e4, controlling the center
moves_detailed.commentary: The most popular opening move, controlling the center and freeing the queen and bishop for development. This move is the foundation of many aggressive openings.

moves_detailed.description: Black responds with e5, controlling the center
moves_detailed.commentary: The symmetrical response. Black mirrors White's strategy by also controlling the center. This creates a balanced position where both sides have equal chances.

moves_detailed.description: White develops the knight to f3, attacking e5
moves_detailed.commentary: Natural development, attacking the e5 pawn and preparing for castling. This is the most common move in this position and sets up the King's Knight Opening.

moves_detailed.description: Black plays d6, supporting e5 and preparing Philidor Defense
moves_detailed.commentary: The Philidor Defense. Black supports the e5 pawn and prepares to develop the bishop to e7. This is a solid but somewhat passive approach that was popular in the 19th century.

moves_detailed.description: White plays d4, challenging the center and opening lines
moves_detailed.commentary: White challenges Black's central pawn with d4. This move opens lines for the queen and bishop while creating tension in the center. It's a natural continuation that aims to control more central space.

moves_detailed.description: Black develops the bishop to g4, pinning the knight
moves_detailed.commentary: Black pins the knight to the queen with Bg4. However, as Fischer noted, this is already a weak move. The pin can be easily broken, and it doesn't contribute to Black's development or control of the center.

moves_detailed.description: White captures the e5 pawn, breaking the pin
moves_detailed.commentary: White breaks the pin by capturing the e5 pawn. This forces Black to either recapture or lose the pawn, and it opens up the position for White's pieces.

moves_detailed.description: Black captures the knight, but gives up the bishop pair
moves_detailed.commentary: Black captures the knight, but this gives up the bishop pair and doesn't solve Black's development problems. White will recapture with the queen, gaining time and central control.

moves_detailed.description: White recaptures with the queen, gaining central control
moves_detailed.commentary: White recaptures with the queen, gaining central control and development. The queen is now actively placed and can participate in the attack.

moves_detailed.description: Black recaptures the pawn, but the position remains difficult
moves_detailed.commentary: Black recaptures the pawn, but the position remains difficult. Black is behind in development and White has better piece coordination.

moves_detailed.description: White develops the bishop to c4, targeting f7
moves_detailed.commentary: White develops the bishop to c4, targeting the weak f7 square. This is a very active placement that puts pressure on Black's kingside.

moves_detailed.description: Black develops the knight to f6, defending the kingside
moves_detailed.commentary: Black develops the knight to f6, defending the kingside. This is a natural development move, but Black is still behind in development.

moves_detailed.description: White moves the queen to b3, creating multiple threats
moves_detailed.commentary: White moves the queen to b3, creating multiple threats. The queen now attacks the b7 pawn and supports the bishop on c4, creating a powerful battery.

moves_detailed.description: Black moves the queen to e7, defending the b7 pawn
moves_detailed.commentary: Black moves the queen to e7 to defend the b7 pawn, but this blocks the bishop's development and creates coordination problems.

moves_detailed.description: White develops the knight to c3, completing development
moves_detailed.commentary: White develops the knight to c3, completing the development of the minor pieces. White now has all pieces developed and ready for action.

moves_detailed.description: Black plays c6, defending the b7 pawn but blocking the bishop
moves_detailed.commentary: Black plays c6 to defend the b7 pawn, but this blocks the bishop's development and creates further coordination problems. Black is in what's like a zugzwang position here.

moves_detailed.description: White develops the bishop to g5, pinning the knight
moves_detailed.commentary: White develops the bishop to g5, pinning the knight to the queen. This creates additional pressure and prevents Black from castling easily.

moves_detailed.description: Black plays b5, trying to gain space but weakening the position
moves_detailed.commentary: Black plays b5 to gain space, but this weakens the position and creates more targets for White to attack. The pawn advance doesn't solve Black's development problems.

moves_detailed.description: White captures the b5 pawn with the knight
moves_detailed.commentary: White captures the b5 pawn with the knight. This is a tactical shot that gains material and creates more pressure on Black's position.

moves_detailed.description: Black recaptures with the c-pawn
moves_detailed.commentary: Black recaptures with the c-pawn, but this doesn't solve the fundamental problems in the position. White still has a significant advantage.

moves_detailed.description: White captures the b5 pawn with check
moves_detailed.commentary: White captures the b5 pawn with check. This forces Black to respond and creates more tactical opportunities for White.

moves_detailed.description: Black blocks the check with the knight
moves_detailed.commentary: Black blocks the check with the knight, but this further complicates Black's development and creates more coordination problems.

moves_detailed.description: White castles queenside, connecting the rooks
moves_detailed.commentary: White castles queenside, connecting the rooks and bringing the king to safety. This also prepares for a powerful rook attack on the d-file.

moves_detailed.description: Black moves the rook to d8, contesting the d-file
moves_detailed.commentary: Black moves the rook to d8 to contest the d-file, but this doesn't address the fundamental problems in the position. White still has a significant advantage.

moves_detailed.description: White captures the knight with the rook
moves_detailed.commentary: White captures the knight with the rook. This is a powerful move that gains material and creates more tactical opportunities. The rook is now very active on the 7th rank.

moves_detailed.description: Black recaptures with the rook
moves_detailed.commentary: Black recaptures with the rook, but this doesn't solve the fundamental problems. White still has a significant advantage and more active pieces.

moves_detailed.description: White moves the rook from h1 to d1, doubling rooks on the d-file
moves_detailed.commentary: White moves the rook from h1 to d1, doubling rooks on the d-file. This creates tremendous pressure on Black's position and prepares for the final assault.

moves_detailed.description: Black moves the queen to e6, trying to defend
moves_detailed.commentary: Black moves the queen to e6, trying to defend, but this doesn't address the fundamental problems. White's position is overwhelming and the attack is unstoppable.

moves_detailed.description: White captures the knight with check
moves_detailed.commentary: White captures the knight with check. This is a brilliant tactical shot that forces Black to recapture, leading to the final combination.

moves_detailed.description: Black recaptures with the knight
moves_detailed.commentary: Black recaptures with the knight, but this doesn't solve the fundamental problems. White's attack is now unstoppable.

moves_detailed.description: White moves the queen to b8 with check
moves_detailed.commentary: White moves the queen to b8 with check. This is a devastating move that forces Black to block with the knight, leading to the final checkmate.

moves_detailed.description: Black blocks with the knight
moves_detailed.commentary: Black blocks with the knight, but this is the final move before checkmate. White's rook will now deliver the final blow.

moves_detailed.description: White delivers checkmate with the rook
moves_detailed.commentary: White delivers checkmate with the rook! This is the famous conclusion of the Opera Game. Morphy's brilliant tactical sequence has led to a beautiful checkmate. The game is a masterpiece of chess artistry and tactical brilliance.

games.facts: The Opera Game is one of the most famous games in chess history, played by Paul Morphy against the Duke of Brunswick and Count Isouard in 1858 at the Paris Opera. Morphy was only 21 years old at the time and was already considered one of the strongest players in the world. This game demonstrates Morphy's brilliant tactical vision and piece coordination. The game is famous for its beautiful tactical combinations and the way Morphy sacrifices material to create a winning attack. The Opera Game is studied by chess players of all levels as a perfect example of how to recognize and execute tactical combinations. Morphy's play in this game is considered a masterpiece of chess artistry and tactical brilliance. The game shows the importance of piece coordination, tactical vision, and the power of sacrificing material for positional and tactical advantages. This game is often used as a teaching tool to demonstrate advanced tactical concepts and the beauty of chess combinations.

games.name: Back Rank Mate in 2
games.description: Back Rank Mate based on the Legal Trap

moves_detailed.description: White opens with e4, controlling the center
moves_detailed.commentary: The most popular opening move, controlling the center and freeing the queen and bishop for development.

moves_detailed.description: Black responds with e5, mirroring white's strategy
moves_detailed.commentary: The symmetrical response, also controlling the center. This leads to an open game with equal chances.

moves_detailed.description: White develops the knight to f3, attacking e5
moves_detailed.commentary: Natural development, attacking the e5 pawn and preparing for castling.

moves_detailed.description: Black develops the knight to c6, defending e5
moves_detailed.commentary: Standard development, defending the e5 pawn.

moves_detailed.description: White plays the Ruy Lopez opening
moves_detailed.commentary: The Ruy Lopez opening, one of the most popular and well-studied openings in chess.

moves_detailed.description: Black plays the Morphy Defense
moves_detailed.commentary: The Morphy Defense, asking White what he intends to do with the bishop.

moves_detailed.description: White retreats the bishop to a4
moves_detailed.commentary: White retreats the bishop, maintaining pressure on the knight.

moves_detailed.description: Black plays d6, supporting the center
moves_detailed.commentary: Black supports the e5 pawn and prepares for piece development.

moves_detailed.description: White plays c4, gaining space
moves_detailed.commentary: White gains space and prepares for further development.

moves_detailed.description: Black develops the bishop to d7
moves_detailed.commentary: Black develops the bishop, preparing to castle.

moves_detailed.description: White develops the knight to c3
moves_detailed.commentary: White develops the knight, completing the development of minor pieces.

moves_detailed.description: Black plays g6, preparing to fianchetto
moves_detailed.commentary: Black prepares to fianchetto the bishop.

moves_detailed.description: White plays d4, challenging the center
moves_detailed.commentary: White challenges Black's central pawn with d4.

moves_detailed.description: Black develops the bishop to g7
moves_detailed.commentary: Black completes the fianchetto development.

moves_detailed.description: White develops the bishop to e3
moves_detailed.commentary: White develops the bishop to an active square.

moves_detailed.description: Black develops the knight to f6
moves_detailed.commentary: Black develops the knight, completing the development of minor pieces.

moves_detailed.description: White captures e5 with the d-pawn
moves_detailed.commentary: White captures the e5 pawn, opening the position.

moves_detailed.description: Black recaptures with the d-pawn
moves_detailed.commentary: Black recaptures, maintaining material balance.

moves_detailed.description: White moves the bishop to c5
moves_detailed.commentary: White moves the bishop to a more active position.

moves_detailed.description: Black moves the knight to h5
moves_detailed.commentary: Black repositions the knight.

moves_detailed.description: White moves the knight to d5
moves_detailed.commentary: White centralizes the knight, putting pressure on Black's position.

moves_detailed.description: Black moves the knight to f4
moves_detailed.commentary: Black repositions the knight to f4.

moves_detailed.description: White captures the knight on f4
moves_detailed.commentary: White captures the knight, gaining material.

moves_detailed.description: Black recaptures with the e-pawn
moves_detailed.commentary: Black recaptures with the e-pawn.

moves_detailed.description: White advances the e-pawn
moves_detailed.commentary: White advances the e-pawn, gaining space and creating threats.

moves_detailed.description: Black advances the g-pawn
moves_detailed.commentary: Black advances the g-pawn.

moves_detailed.description: White moves the queen to d5
moves_detailed.commentary: White centralizes the queen, creating multiple threats.

moves_detailed.description: Black moves the bishop to f8
moves_detailed.commentary: Black repositions the bishop.

moves_detailed.description: White captures the bishop on f8
moves_detailed.commentary: White captures the bishop, gaining material.

moves_detailed.description: Black recaptures with the rook
moves_detailed.commentary: Black recaptures with the rook.

moves_detailed.description: White castles queenside
moves_detailed.commentary: White castles queenside, bringing the king to safety and connecting the rooks.

moves_detailed.description: Black moves the queen to e7
moves_detailed.commentary: Black develops the queen.

moves_detailed.description: White captures the knight on c6
moves_detailed.commentary: White captures the knight, gaining material and opening lines.

moves_detailed.description: Black recaptures with the bishop
moves_detailed.commentary: Black recaptures with the bishop.

moves_detailed.description: White moves the queen to d3
moves_detailed.commentary: White repositions the queen, maintaining pressure.

moves_detailed.description: Black moves the bishop to d7
moves_detailed.commentary: Black repositions the bishop.

moves_detailed.description: White captures the g-pawn with the knight
moves_detailed.commentary: White captures the g-pawn, gaining material and creating threats.

moves_detailed.description: Black castles queenside
moves_detailed.commentary: Black castles queenside, bringing the king to safety.

moves_detailed.description: White moves the knight to f3
moves_detailed.commentary: White repositions the knight, maintaining control.

moves_detailed.description: Black plays f6
moves_detailed.commentary: Black plays f6, trying to create counterplay.

moves_detailed.description: White captures f6 with the e-pawn
moves_detailed.commentary: White captures f6, opening lines and creating threats.

moves_detailed.description: Black recaptures with the rook

moves_detailed.description: White moves the rook to e1
moves_detailed.commentary: White doubles rooks on the e-file, creating powerful threats.

moves_detailed.description: Black moves the queen to b4

moves_detailed.description: White captures the bishop with check
moves_detailed.commentary: White captures the bishop with check, gaining material and creating a winning position.

moves_detailed.description: Black recaptures with the rook

moves_detailed.description: White moves the rook to e8 with check
moves_detailed.commentary: White delivers checkmate! The rook on e8 gives check, and Black has no way to escape or block the check. This is the famous back rank mate pattern.

games.facts: Test version of the Legal Trap - one of the most famous tactical combinations in chess history, named after Legall de Kermeur who played it in 1750. This duplicate is created for testing purposes.

games.name: Molinari – Bordais (1979)
games.description: Rare knight mate – White's Nbc3 blocks the c-pawn and allows Black's knight to invade d3

moves_detailed.description: White opens with e4, controlling the center
Black plays the Sicilian Defense
White plays c4, the English-style setup
Black develops the knight to c6
White develops the knight to e2
Black develops the knight to f6
White plays Nbc3 – a subtle but decisive mistake
moves_detailed.commentary: Allows Black's knight to jump into b4 and d3 with no way to chase it away. White's setup looks solid but fatally neglects control of d3.

moves_detailed.description: Black's knight jumps to b4, threatening d3
moves_detailed.commentary: The knight heads for the decisive d3 square. White has no way to prevent or chase it away.

moves_detailed.description: White plays g3, attempting to fianchetto
moves_detailed.commentary: Allows black to mate in 1.

moves_detailed.description: Black delivers a rare knight mate
moves_detailed.commentary: A rare knight mate: the knight is protected, the king has no escape squares, and White's undeveloped pieces and blocked pawns make defense impossible.

games.facts: A rare knight mate from 1979. White's 4.Nbc3? is a subtle but fatal mistake—it blocks the c-pawn, removes the c2-square, and allows Black's knight to invade b4 and then d3 with no way to chase it away. The knight on d3 delivers checkmate, protected and unstoppable, while White's undeveloped pieces and blocked pawns make defense impossible.

games.name: C. Gurnhill – H. Banks (1984)
games.description: Caro-Kann smothered mate – Black's pawn grab and Ngf6 allow White's knight to deliver Nd6#

moves_detailed.description: White opens with e4, controlling the center
Black plays the Caro-Kann Defense
White claims the center with d4
Black challenges the center
White develops the knight
Black grabs a pawn, but this opens lines and neglects development
moves_detailed.commentary: Black grabs a pawn, but this opens lines and neglects development; the center will be vulnerable.

moves_detailed.description: White recaptures with the knight
Black develops the knight
White develops the queen
Black develops the knight but leaves the back rank weak
moves_detailed.commentary: Develops a piece but leaves h8–a1 diagonal and back rank weak; sets up the smothered mate.

moves_detailed.description: White delivers smothered mate
moves_detailed.commentary: Smothered mate: the knight exploits the trapped king, with all escape squares blocked by its own pieces.

games.facts: A Caro-Kann miniature from 1984. Black's 3...dxe4?! grabs a pawn but opens lines and neglects development. After 5...Ngf6?!, Black develops a piece but leaves the h8–a1 diagonal and back rank fatally weak. White's 6.Nd6# delivers a classic smothered mate—the knight exploits the trapped king with all escape squares blocked by its own pieces.

games.name: Scholar's Mate Puzzle

moves_detailed.description: White plays e4
Black plays e5
White brings out the queen to h5, threatening checkmate
moves_detailed.commentary: The key move of Scholar's Mate! White brings out the queen early to threaten the f7 square.

moves_detailed.description: Black develops the knight to c6
moves_detailed.commentary: A natural developing move, but it doesn't address White's threat. Black should have played Nf6 to defend the f7 square.

moves_detailed.description: White develops the bishop to c4, supporting the queen
moves_detailed.commentary: Perfect! White develops the bishop to c4, creating a powerful battery with the queen.

moves_detailed.description: Black develops the knight to f6, attacking the queen
moves_detailed.commentary: A critical mistake! Black attacks the queen but doesn't realize that White can simply move the queen to f7 for checkmate.

moves_detailed.description: White delivers checkmate with Qf7#
moves_detailed.commentary: Checkmate! White delivers the final blow by moving the queen to f7. The king is trapped and has no escape squares.

games.facts: Scholar's Mate puzzle version - find the 4-move checkmate pattern. This is a classic tactical puzzle that teaches the importance of defending the f7 square.
